Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: Sorry to start a new thread about this, but hoping I can get more responses with this new subject line.... I was over my UTI, all pain was gone, I was feeling good.  Onc said to try the Fareston again and see if pelvic pain came back.  I've been on it about a week now, and dang it if I didn't start noticing some UTI-like symptoms again today.     These are more like "traditional" UTI symptoms, rather than the odd pain from before.  I have Googled and Binged (is that a word - lol) and I'm not coming up with anything, so I've come back to the wisest group of people I know.  I know about the typical side effects from medicines (hot flashes, etc.), but I have never heard of one giving you a UTI.  Is this just a conincidence?  I'm thinking not, since I have never had a UTI in my life till now and I'm doing anything else different...the only thing new is the Fareston.  I hate to stop this drug, but I don't think continual UTI's (or symptoms like it) are things I can tolerate long-term.  Do I keep taking the pill and see if it gets worse, or should I stop now before it gets worse?!  I'm so upset and disappointed and well, just plain lost.  I don't know what to do now.  HELP me please wise ladies (and gentlemen)!!  Thank you! ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I was diagnosed with mets in November 2004.  I don't remember the exact date, but know it was sometime in November.  So, this month I'm celebrating SEVEN years LIVING with mets!!   One year after my mets dx, I married the love of my life.  This Friday, on 11/11/11, (I think that date is so cool!) we will celebrate our six year wedding anniversary!  We are going to Savannah for a long weekend to celebrate.  I am so very grateful that I feel up to taking this trip.  We were not able to do anything last year for our 5th because I felt so bad. Cancer has taken a lot of things from me, but the one thing it has given to me is appreciation.  I appreciate EVERYTHING so much more than I ever did.  I see the sunrise, I smell the roses, and I live life more fully than I ever have.  I have never been to Savannah and realize I may never get to go again, so I will be soaking up every single moment - doing all the touristy stuff and spending quality time with my awesome hubby. I want to say thank you to this board for being here for me on the good days and the bad. You've cheered with me at good scan results, and bolstered me through progression and side effects.  Thank you for being here and for all your support.  Much love to you all! ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2010 07:38AM Lynn1 wrote: I was originally started on Abraxane and Avastin eariler this year.  I only took 2 or 3 (can't remember) of the Avastin and had to stop due to nosebleeds.  Onc actually writes that it is "on hold" rather than "stopped" because he said Avastin is only approved for first-line and if we stop it, then they will not approve it again.  It IS insanely expensive...$7,000 a treatment, twice a month!  I will get my latest scan results tomorrow and I'm very anxious to see if there was any change with discontinuing the Avastin.  In my non-medical opinion, if things are still stable, then I don't see any reason to add the Avastin back in.  My onc admitted that it is "a very toxic drug" and I'm just getting the nosebleeds under control, so I really don't want to take it anymore.  Of course, if there is progression, I guess it's not "first line" anymore anyway...I don't know. I'm not sure if there is anything else you can do unfortunately since it's already been to the review panel.  Once when I switched to my DH's insurance for awhile, they would not cover PET scans.  We tried and tried, onc talked to them directly, and they would not budge, so we just had to do different scans to get the images he wanted.  Ironically, those several scans cost more than the one PET so it made NO sense to me, but that is how insurance can be.  Frustrating isn't it?!  Best of luck to you whatever your decision is.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 07:25AM - edited Feb 17, 2011 07:26AM by Lynn1 Ok friends, I have been paying much more attention to my pain - when it occurs, when it is worse, etc., and I am starting to think this is indeed more bowel related than bladder.  I know the Fareston causes contipation, and I'm trying my best to ease that....I eat high fiber foods and also take fiber supplements with dinner, I also eat a prune each night, and I take 2 stool softeners each night too - and yet I still have trouble.  Last night it was hurting and I felt my stomach (below your belly-button) and it was hard and I looked very bloated.  I looked up the anatomy in that area and all I see is small intestine, which just makes me think more that I just have a back-up of poo in there. How nice is that?!  (sorry so graphic).  I really don't want to take a laxative, as that usually sends me waaay off in the other direction and, to me, that is worse.  Today I'm going to try lots water and see if that helps. What do you all think? Could the pain from constipation be causing pain such as this?  Sorry to sound so stupid....I've just never had this before really -- prior to BC, I was always a very regular girl.   What can I do to make it better?  And, do you think this is something I can treat at home, or should I see a doctor?  Thank you!!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I would like to get your opinions please.  I have mets to my pelvis - specifically the right iliac crest and the left ileum.  The right side is the largest - measuring in at 41 mm.  In the past week, I have started to have pain on the right side -- not bad...in fact I'm trying to avoid taking anything for it, but it is still making its presence known.  I am worried that the Femara is not working and is allowing the met to grow and cause this pain.  I do several stretches in the evening and one of them I lay on my back and roll gently from side to side - it usually feels great, but now it's as if I can feel something on the right side...a "lump" for lack of a better word.  It is not on the left.  It does not hurt worse when I roll onto it, but it feels weird.  The first time I felt it, I looked to make sure I wasn't laying on something -- that is sorta how it feels....like I had rolled onto a big wrinkle in my clothes or something - hope that made sense. I'm pretty sure if I call the onc, he is going to say that we have to give the Femara the 3 months to work.  I've been on it only about 3 weeks now.  And scans (PET and MRI) were done about 3 weeks ago too, so there is no way he is going to do any more tests now.  It just seems a waste of time to even call so I have not.  I have so much fun stuff planned in the next couple of months so this worries me.  I don't want to cancel anything, but I worry that it will get worse and then I won't feel like doing anything, but on the other hand, the onc isn't going to do anything till June.   What would you all do?  Anything?  Thanks so much for your advice. ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 06:45AM Lynn1 wrote: Hi, I have several bone mets.  Faslodex did not work for me, but as you see it does work quite well for some.  I hope you will be one of the ones it works for since it is a very tolerable option.  My understanding on the bone mets is not so much how many there are, but that it stays in the bone.  I recently had some progression where it popped up in some new bones, but my onc was still optomistic reminding me that you can live for many years with bone-only mets.  Please don't give up hope!! As for work, that is a very difficult and personal decision.  For me, I have the better insurance and income, and I enjoy it for the most part so I like to keep going.  However, I have recently decided to request telecomuting 2 days a week to lighten the stress some.  Maybe that would be an option for you....to not quit entirely, but just cut back?  Best of luck to you no matter what you decide.

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: Well, I knew this was going to happen eventually, but I really did not expect this news today.  Xeloda is no longer working.  I've had progression in both size and number since my last scan 3 months ago.  It is still contained to bone only, so that is good news.  I loved Xeloda, so I'm particularly bummed that it stopped working.  I did get 11 months out of it, so I guess that is something to be thankful for.  I think I'm still a bit stunned from the news....not sure it's all sank in yet.  I feel so good!! How can such bad things be going on inside me?!  :(    I guess the other good news is that this is the only chemo I have failed, so there's a lot of options left.  My onc said I might qualify for a study - he's checking on it for me.  Sounds to me like it might be Afinitor.  If I do not qualify, he listed about 10 different chemo names - all of which I've seen on here.  In a way, it's almost like he's leaving it up to me....you have all these choices..which one do you want to try first?  I understand that no one knows if it will work or not , so any one's guess is as good as the other.  He agreed that we should try the more "gentle" ones first and leave the "big guns" (like Taxol) for later. So what I really really need from you all is some input on what to do!!  If you had your choice, which chemo would you want?  Are there any that don't make you lose your hair?!  I know it's silly to some, but hair is important to me.  But of course so are other se's.....which ones have been "easy" for you?  I know everyone is different but just looking for some input here.  I really don't know where to start - it's almost like I have too many options right now (which is a good problem to have, I know), but I don't know where to begin to make this decision.  My head is spinning right now.  Help!!! ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2012 07:19AM Lynn1 wrote: Thanks everyone for your input!  I have already been on all the AIs (Femara, Arimidex, Aromisin, Faslodex, Tamoxifen).  Navelbine and Gemzar were two he mentioned.  He did say that Gemzar can be hard on your counts, and most of his patients have to skip treatments because of it.  From what I've read, there is a possibility of keeping your hair on Navelbine. Baseball Fan:  Sorry to hear of your TMs rising.  Hope you can continue to stay on X. I guess my plan right now is to wait till Monday and hope to speak with either the onc or a nurse to get more info on my options.  I don't know what happened to me.  I was listening, but I should have taken notes.  I can't remember all the details now.  He was telling me about how some are every week, some are 3 weeks on then a week off, and the infusion times vary of course.  I want to take all those into consideration when making this decision - since I'm being given the option.  I hate that they have to repeat it all again, but I totally spaced out for a bit there I guess.  I just kept thinking to myself "what?"....it's all so surreal. Maybe when I have narrowed it down to 2 or 3 choices, I can post and get real-life stories on each one and then hopefully make a good informed decision.   I still feel in shock.  I feel so good and people lately have been telling me how good I look now.  I should have known it was some sort of jinx.  I'm not superstitous, but things have been going so well lately, I guess it was bound to end.  I'm just so sad right now.  I hope I can shake these feelings of despair and get my fighting gloves back on soon.   This just sucks!!

Posts.Content: May 14, 2010 07:15AM Lynn1 wrote: When my mets were first dxd, they had me do a brain MRI - I think just to make sure nothing had spread there too.  They have never mentioned one again (it has been almost 6 years).  It was very scary, but at the same time, I was glad/relieved to know they did not find anything.  I guess to answer your question, yes, I would have it done.  If there is anything there, I would want to start treating it right away, and if there is not, then you have that peace of mind (no pun intended).  Anyway, just my 2 cents.....   Best of luck to you no matter what you decide.

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: Hi All!  So I had posted recently about the pain in my sternum increasing and how scared I was that the cancer was getting worse on this treatment.  I was really freaking out and have been very worried.  I can't explain it, but in the last couple of days, the pain has subsided quite a bit - to the point even that yesterday I only took Aleve and was fine.  I hope I don't jinx myself by posting this!  LOL!  Anyway, now that the pain is less, my fears have also subsided somewhat.  It's not like I'm no longer worried, but it's just not AS intense.  I can't totally explain that either since there have been many times in the past where things were progressing and yet I had no symptoms.  So, just throwing this out for discussion....does anyone think there is a link between the amount of pain and our fears or beliefs about what is going on?  Does the pain magnify what we are already thinking?  Or is it all just a conincidence?  Just curious what others think about this..... ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: Ok, I know this test is not reliable for everyone, but I'm trying to educate myself about them more and I hope someone can help me out with a question....What is considered a noteworthy change on TMs? I see some people post that theirs dropped/increased by 5 points or so and they are happy/worried.  Is 5 points really a big deal, or not until the change is larger...say 50 points?  Or is this another area where it varies by person?.....A 5 point drop for one person might be great, while 5 points for someone else is nothing.  I know they vary and variances are to be expected and not worried about so much, but if you see a "trend" -- increasing or decreasing.....at what point does that number become significant?  And in case you're wondering what prompted my question......my latest test shows a drop of 18 points.  Fluke?  Good sign?  Happy Dance?? No big deal?? Posts.Content: May 14, 2010 07:10AM Lynn1 wrote: As I understand it, you are considered stable if it is not greatly progressing.  For example, I have mets to my sternum - have had it there for years now.  The scans all show it is there, but since the size is the same, they still call it stable.  You do say the bone scan had a couple new small lesions....I would have to assume they are still calling her stable because the spots are so small.  My guess is they will monitor the new lesions closely and if they start to grow or become more numerous, they will change the treatment. Hope this helps!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I know there is a thread about Femara, but it's about 70 pages long now....so I hope no one minds if I start a new one on this specific topic. I took Femara for about 5 years and never noticed any change in my weight.  However, I have been on it for about 3 weeks now, and I seem to be gaining.  I don't understand.  I am following the Weight Watchers plan that I've been on for years, I've started going back to the gym about 3 times a week, and I've started drinking more water lately too, and yet the scale keeps creeping up.  Someone suggested it could be the Femara.  I just don't see how that is possible.  Why would it make me gain weight now and not before?  And, I just don't understand how that "works" anyway.  Does anyone know how a medicine can make you gain weight?  I always thought weight gain/loss really came down to calories in/calories out.  I'm stressing over this because my trip to the beach is in 5 weeks, and I'm gaining instead of losing!!  :( Any insight/advice/tips on this will be very much appreciated. ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. I have to carry a tissue everywhere I go!!  My nose is red like Rudolph and it's raw and sore and peeling from all the tissues - and I'm using the ones with lotion.  I asked onc last week if this was from the Xeloda and he said no, but I disagree.  I've never had anything like this before, and it started about the time I started the Xeloda.  I've tried Claritin and now Claritin-D and no change.  Anyone else have this? Did you ever find anything that helped?  PS - also, my eyes are watery.  I know this sounds like allergy symptoms, but there is nothing blooming out there - I checked and our local pollen count right now is very very low.  Help! ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 09:52AM Lynn1 wrote: Hi Bev!  Great news on your hanging with the Stable Boy!!  Yippie!! Aromisin was the only AI that I could not take.  You know how when you sleep wrong and you get a kink in your neck and it hurts like crazy and you can hardly move?  That was me on Arominsin, but it was all over my body.  I could barely walk from the bed to the couch.  I hated to pass up an option, but that was not tolerable for me.  So I understand where you're coming from on that one! I can't take pain meds either - they make me soooo sick (vomiting).  If I have to take them, I have to take an anti-nausea med first.  So after my little episode last week, pain meds were top of my list of questions today.   I was talking to the NP (who I just don't like and don't think he's very good) so I'll confirm more next week with my real doctor, but he said pain patches would be the best long-lasting option and people can function on them (no zombies). Then you can take a pill (Percoset, etc.) for any breakthrough pain.  Sorry I don't have more info on them, but hopefully someone else will.  I'm VERY interested in the answers you get!!

Posts.Title: Port Questions Lynn1 CelineFlower

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2012 02:14PM Lynn1 wrote: Thank you all so much for the thoughts and prayers!!  I apologize for not updating here yesterday.  I was so "out of it" from the anesthesia, and I just didn't feel like typing much.  The surgeon told DH that all went very well from his perspective, so that's good. The nurse brought me back and told me to change into the "pretty" gown and socks.  She told me I could keep my underwear on and I immediately thought of Jennifer sitting there alone in her gown and no underwear. Made me smile.  Not at her situation but that at that very moment, my thoughts turned you all here and it gave me comfort.   I did have to walk from the pre-op area into the OR.  They were very nice though and put down a nice warm blanket so I didn't have to lay on that cold metal, and as soon as I laid down she had another warm blanket on top of me.  Ahhh.  They called this twillight sleep, but I was O.U.T.  He said "ok, you'll be out in about 20 seconds...enjoy your nap", and the next thing I knew I was in recovery. Then the "fun" began.  They needed a chest x-ray to make sure it was all in the right place.  I thought to myself that now is heck of a time to check - are you going to go back in if it's "wrong"?!  Anyway, there was no raising that arm over my head so I ended up leaning against the wall with my hands out in front of me (made me laugh a little though since I figured I looked like someone being arrested rather than x-rayed).  Then we had to wait for them to read it.  I just wanted to go home!  Took forever, but all was well I guess and they sent me home.  I slept most of the day away. It is really sore this morning still.  I don't do pain meds well so I've been popping Advil like crazy.  I think it's worse because it's on my right side and I'm right handed.  I keep reaching for stuff and "OW!!".    I hope some of this is just the dressing pulling and it will be better when I can get that off.  I'm taking today off.  All of you who went back to work right away after this are superwomen!! There is no way I could feel safe driving today, much less feel like working.   I am so curious what it looks like and how far it sticks out and all.  They told me not to take off the dressing for 48 hours so that would not be till tomorrow morning.  They are going to call me sometime today to check on me so I'm going to ask if I could do that tonight instead.  I'm supposed to be at the onc for 1st chemo at 8:15am tomorrow.  I need time to put that cream on and all. Thanks again to everyone who supported and encouraged me as I waited for this.  I finally lost it on Tuesday night and cried myself to sleep.  I haven't done that since my original dx, and I guess it helped some to just get it all out.  The surgery itself was not as bad as I thought, but so far I'm still not excited about having this alien in my chest.  Maybe after chemo tomorrow, it will be my best friend like it is to so many of you.  Thanks again - you all are the best!!
Posts.Title: Port Questions Lynn1 CelineFlower

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2012 09:34AM Lynn1 wrote: CoolBreeze:  That sure stinks for you not being able to enjoy the twilight sleep!  The soreness is going away a little each day.  So far, no issues with seatbelts and such!  :) So here is today's update: Got up early and got DH to "supervise" my removing the dressing.  It hurt like crazy pulling it off slowly, but I was afraid to just rip it off! Anyway, finally got it and boy does it feel good to not have all that tape pulling on the skin!  I was very surprised - it is smaller than I thought!  I hope it does not "grow" as it heals.  So the onc said to put the EMLA cream on the port itself, not on the incision. Well, they are together!  I only have one incision and it's right above the port from what I can tell.  There are still steri-strips covering it all and it's bruised of course so hard to see.  So I decided not to put anything on it since he said "not on the incision".  Thought it might burn or something.  Anyway, I get there and explain what is going on.  They actually used it through the steri-strips.  Said they wanted to just let those fall off.  So of course no EMLA cream.  I jokingly told them to give me something to bite on, but I was very surprised that it did not hurt much at all.  The pressure of her pushing on it hurt worse than the actual stick! It had good blood return and so all seems to be working great!  I will say that I did enjoy having my hands free the entire time.  That was a nice change from "try not to move your arm" for 2 hours.  So, hopefully I'm on my way to a friendship with my new alien.  Thank you all soooo much for baby-stepping me through this!!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: Finally some good news!!! The Xeloda is working!!!  My PET scan was mostly "unremarkable" (I love that word!) with good reduction in SUV amounts -- sternum from 5.0 down to 1.3; pelvis from 5.5 down to 2.0, and "no new lesions are noted"!!  The MRI report showed that the mets in the pelvis stayed the same size, but there was significantly less edema around them which suggests improvement. A small number of lesions were also decreased in size by 10%! I am soooo happy!!!  I've had several bad scan reports in a row, so it felt so great to get some good news for a change! I can't stop smiling!! So, hello again Stable Boy...you better stay around this time 'cause now I'm flirting with Reggie and I'll leave you in a second for him!!     Happy Dance Time!!!! ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2012 05:39PM Lynn1 wrote: I have the same status as you.  I started out with the hormones, and they kept me stable for several years.  It is only now that I have exhausted all the hormone options that I am on chemo.  I would ask about the hormones as, generally speaking, they are easier to tolerate than chemo, but they might want to hit it hard at first with the chemo, and then once you get stable put you on the hormones.  Everyone is so different.  Best of luck to you!  Oh, and I never had a bone biopsy.

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2012 12:14PM Lynn1 wrote: Ok, I guess this is all normal then.  Thanks for all your help!  I have to say that I do not like this though.  Yes, low on the list of problems, but wish it didn't have to be bruised ALL the time.  I have always had slow-to-fade bruises so it juuuuust starts to go away and then it's time to do it again!  I kept thinking it was sore/tender because of the bruising and that when that went away it would feel better, but it never gets a chance to go away.  It will be a month this Wednesday since the surgery.  I guess I'd hoped I'd be all good by now.  The area is bruised, and right in the middle is a very visible "dot" where the needle was.  It is also sensitive - can feel shirt rubbing on it (and I'm wearing a soft t-shirt.) :-\ What really ticked me off this last visit was they took my blood through the port.  Then they decided since my platelets were so low, they wanted to check them again. Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2012 06:12AM Lynn1 wrote: Cynthia:  I guess you could already be having surgery if I read your post right, but thought I'd go ahead and answer just in case.... When I went in for my consultation they brought in a "regular" port.  The thing looked HUGE!  My DH said it looked like a volcano.  LOL!  Anyway, I said, is that a power port? She said no, and asked if that was what I wanted.  After reading all the stories here, I knew I did want one.  She said that would not be a problem, they would put in whatever I wanted, and here I sit with a purple "gum drop" by my shoulder.  (I showed a picture of the port to a co-worker and she said it looked like a grape gum drop.  LOL!   Now I can't get that image out of my head!) I know they are limited to where they can place it, but hopefully he can get it on the opposite side and not have to risk your lymphedema side.  I was pretty zonked out most of the day of the surgery.  I could have stayed awake if I had to, but I really just wanted to sleep.  The 2nd day wasn't horrible, but I did take the day off work - it was just uncomfortable.  But, I dont' have kids, soooo can't help there. I hope that the smaller hospital treats you extra special.  Let us know how it goes!  HUGS!!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: Finally some good news!!! The Xeloda is working!!!  My PET scan was mostly "unremarkable" (I love that word!) with good reduction in SUV amounts -- sternum from 5.0 down to 1.3; pelvis from 5.5 down to 2.0, and "no new lesions are noted"!!  The MRI report showed that the mets in the pelvis stayed the same size, but there was significantly less edema around them which suggests improvement. A small number of lesions were also decreased in size by 10%! I am soooo happy!!!  I've had several bad scan reports in a row, so it felt so great to get some good news for a change! I can't stop smiling!! So, hello again Stable Boy...you better stay around this time 'cause now I'm flirting with Reggie and I'll leave you in a second for him!!     Happy Dance Time!!!! ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2012 08:38AM Lynn1 wrote: Lisa:  I really hope you are right!  I'm all for a "blip" - I've been so scared and worried since I got this news.  It's odd to me how it's affecting my red cells and platelets, but not my white cells.  In a way, I guess I'm glad - better to have those white cells defending me from getting sick.  I am not taking Procrit - my doc doesn't think it's a good idea, and I agree with him, but I am not judging anyone who thinks differently on this subject. That's good to know in a way that this might not show up on scans.  I'd be super upset if they missed this.  But I do remember once a while back my onc saying that bone mets are the hardest to track. I do have a little shortness of breath, but I was assuming that was from the anemia.  When I got my transfusion, that eased quite a bit.  But my red cell count is still not what it should be, so I was attributing it to that.  I have not had any cramping, but I do feel tired all the time - no amount of sleep ever fully revives me like it used to. Yes, I was on Xeloda for a year.  Loved it!  I had some issues at first, but we tweaked the dosage and I had hardly any side effects.  I wish it would have worked for longer.  That is great news to hear about how you feel on the Afinitor.  I hope I get to keep taking it too.  Like you, I have read all the possible nasty side effects and I just keep waiting for them to show up, but you've given me hope that maybe I'll be one of the lucky ones who doesn't have too many. Thanks again for all your help - will keep in touch!!
Posts.Title: Bone Marrow is "Packed" with Cancer Cells Lynn1 Heidihill

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I saw the onc today for the results of the bone marrow biopsy.  They were unable to get any liquid bone marrow for their test, and the reason for that is because my bone marrow is "packed" (doctor's words) with cancer cells.  There are so many cancer cells that the marrow can't make blood efficiently and that is why my counts have been so low.  Obviously, we need to kill the cancer cells so the marrow has more room to work. I'm in a bit of limbo right now - not sure what we are going to do.  He wants to consult with the doctor at Emory who was heading up the trials on Afinitor and see if she has any experience with this and if she thinks the Afinitor will work or do we need to go back to a more traditional IV chemo.  He said he would try and get in touch with her today, but it may be Monday before I have any news. In the meantime, unless he calls today and tells me differently, he wants me to start back on the Afinitor tonight and come back in a week for bloodwork.  Has anyone else had this happen?  He said it was not rare, but I've never heard of this before.  Seems very "catch 22" to me -- give me chemo to kill the cancer, but that drops your counts....just seems a vicious circle to me.  I'm trying not to get upset until I know more, but you all know how your mind just races during times like this.  Please send prayers, good vibes, whatever you believe in.  I really need them right now. ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: So yesterday was a routine day, nothing out of the ordinary.  I was watching tv last night, just relaxing before I went to bed.  Then I just started hurting all over!  My hips were the worst, but my low back, my thighs and even my arms were just in such pain!  No way I moved or sat/laid was comfortable!  I took some Aleve, but they didn't do anything, so I took 1/2 a Percoset (pain pills do not agree with me so I take as few as possible).  I was finally able to rest enough that I finally went to sleep. I still feel sore this morning - almost like someone beat me up.  The pain was deep - like my bones were hurting or something - and constant.  This scared me!  Never had anything like that happen before.  I was near tears a couple of times, and very close to having DH take me to the ER.  Has anyone else had this happen? What caused it?  The chemo?....just some crazy fluke??  I did call the nurse line this morning and reported it, but I doubt they will do much since my onc is out of the country on vacation and his NP is a complete idiot.  ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2010 10:29AM Lynn1 wrote: Hello!  Yes, my 1st Zometa was difficult.  I felt so tired and my legs just ached.  This tip was given to me and it has worked wonders....take 2 Tylenol about 10-15 minutes before your infusion.  I do this now and I have little to no side effects.  I have been on monthly Zometa for 5 years. I also believe that doing something (even a short stroll) helps me -- as opposed to just sitting on the couch or whatever.  Not sure how that one works, but I feel much better if I go do something - anything - than I do if I just go sit.  The water is a good idea too.  Hope this helps and hope you feel better soon.

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: This is the 2nd treatment in a row I've missed due to low counts!!  This time it was my platelets.  Their minimum is 100, and mine were 81.  They have almost scared me to death with all their warnings and when to visit the ER. Is 81 really THAT low or are they overreacting?  My white counts made a drastic jump -- guess that's why it hurt so much the other night??  They went from 0.9 to 8.1!!  Woo hoo!  I'm just bummed that I've missed another treatment.  As much as I dislike it, I need it!  Things aren't going to get any better without it!  I think they are going to have to reduce the dose amount a little so I can hopefully be on a more consistent schedule. Posts.Title: Bone Marrow is "Packed" with Cancer Cells Lynn1 Heidihill

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I saw the onc today for the results of the bone marrow biopsy.  They were unable to get any liquid bone marrow for their test, and the reason for that is because my bone marrow is "packed" (doctor's words) with cancer cells.  There are so many cancer cells that the marrow can't make blood efficiently and that is why my counts have been so low.  Obviously, we need to kill the cancer cells so the marrow has more room to work. I'm in a bit of limbo right now - not sure what we are going to do.  He wants to consult with the doctor at Emory who was heading up the trials on Afinitor and see if she has any experience with this and if she thinks the Afinitor will work or do we need to go back to a more traditional IV chemo.  He said he would try and get in touch with her today, but it may be Monday before I have any news. In the meantime, unless he calls today and tells me differently, he wants me to start back on the Afinitor tonight and come back in a week for bloodwork.  Has anyone else had this happen?  He said it was not rare, but I've never heard of this before.  Seems very "catch 22" to me -- give me chemo to kill the cancer, but that drops your counts....just seems a vicious circle to me.  I'm trying not to get upset until I know more, but you all know how your mind just races during times like this.  Please send prayers, good vibes, whatever you believe in.  I really need them right now. ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Started Afinitor/Femara 10/15/12 Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: So I have been having periodic PET scans for 5+ years now.  The only prep I have EVER had was no eating after midnight and drink lots of water (my scans are always early morning).  I have seen here that others have had a different prep and I have asked various people at the facility repeatedly and still get the same answer.  Now I am scheduled for a PET on March 23rd, and they gave me an entire brochure on how to prep!  The day before I'm supposed to not exercise, no caffeine or alcohol, and strictly limit carbs.  Ok, I can do that but I'm just worried...  Is this irrational thinking?.....I'm worried that with such a different prep that they are going to get a "better" scan.  Now, while that is good - I want them to see everything - I'm just stressing that they are going to see something (for example, maybe a spot on a rib) that has been there all along, but was not picked up before due to the different prep.  What I fear is that my onc is going to see that as progression and jump on the chemo bandwagon again.  I guess I will just have to be strong and hold my ground, so to speak.  I have 24 days (but who's counting, right?) till I get the results of the two scans -- will see the onc on March 25th, and I already have some scanxiety, which is kinda unlike me (at least this far out), and I think it's because of the above worries. I feel pretty darn good right now, so I'm choosing to believe the cancer is still stable.  My life goal has become to sit in that exam room on the 25th and say to the onc "I TOLD YOU SO" -- I told you the hormones would work again!!  I want to sit there looking good and healthy and point my finger at him and say SEEE?!!!  You were WRONG!!!   I'm nuts, aren't I?  ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Well, quick update......everything went well yesterday -- all the machines worked, everyone was pretty much on time, and they even found a vein 1st try.  Yay!!   And can you believe I fell asleep in the MRI machine?!  I mean asleep, not just dozing.  I about jumped out of my skin when she came on the intercom thingy to say we were done.  Ok, but I can snooze a few more minutes?!  LOL!   New procedure at the MRI place too -- those of you who hated the big rubber band thing around your feet would "love" this!  They had me take off my shoes, then they put a towel between my feet, turned them so the toes were pointed at each other, and then took that stretchy/sticky tape stuff and wrapped it all around my feet.  I couldn't move at all!  They said this position opens up the pelvis giving them a better view.  So now I wait...tick....tock....tomorrow afternoon will never get here fast enough.  :-\

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 09:16AM Lynn1 wrote: Well, I really did try to take Lowrider's advice and pick a day to start worrying - that was supposed to be next Thursday, but no....it has hit full on already!  I guess it's because this time next week I will be having the scans.  That, and this time feels like such an important one.  If things are still stable, I get to stay on the Fareston at least another 3 months. If there is progression, he is going to lobby hard to get me back on chemo, and I know that once I go back again, it will be forever...he won't ever let me try hormones again.  Some days I feel like this is my last few days to live life normally.  I know that is negative thinking, and that is bad.  I do try so hard to be positive and remind myself that I feel good (in the past, with progression, I've had pain, etc.), so that seems to be a good sign, but I find myself being easily aggitated lately and know it's because deep down I'm scared to death at what these scans will show. To top it all off, my mom is driving me a little crazy right now.  She has some health issues, but won't follow the doctor's instructions completely so that frustrates me.  She is also on a "woe is me" kick right now, and I just so don't need that at this time.  But, I'm an only child and my dad has passed away so that just leaves me.  I am trying to be supportive, but I just feel exhausted after talking with her. Sorry for rambling on. I just needed to get it out I guess, and I knew this is the place where someone might understand.  Thanks for listening.

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: So today I went for "chemo training".  They did not have this the last time I had chemo, and I have to say it was very helpful.  It was one-on-one with his PA.  She gave me a whole folder full information! This is good for me because I like being "over informed" - always feel the need to do lots of research.  Anyway got all my questions answered - almost.  I asked about the Avastin and she said as of today, they are planning to give it to me, but when I come in on Friday, it's possible that may change. If so, I would get the Abraxane only and no Avastin.  Will just have to wait and see - I hate waiting and I hate not knowing. I get to find out right before. Have I mentioned I hate surprises? *sigh* Now that I have asked the question 100 times in 100 ways, it is finally sinking in and I am so very upset about this situation. I've been holding it together pretty well, but now I'm just a crying mess. This is like a bad dream.  I could possibly be on chemo indefinitely and indefinite chemo means indefinite bald and tired and achey and sick.  This cannot be happening. How come no one around me seems to understand..this is huge! Everyone so nonchalant (sp?) - it will be okay. Yeah, really, you know that?!  This is lifechanging. I'm not ready for this. I'm not.  I don't want to go on Friday even though I know I have to.  How do you all DO this? How do you stay so postive and optomistic? I need to go back to DeNile - so much happier there. I feel like my life is changing...on Friday..day after tomorrow...no going back.  This just sucks. :( ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2010 10:19AM Lynn1 wrote: Well, I made it through the 1st chemo!!  Lorainne, you'll be happy to know I walked right in like a normal person - no crying, just finally sucked it up and did it.  It went okay.  They did give me the Avastin. Onc said he thinks it does work, but he will keep an eye on the studies, etc. and also said that if I decide to, we can stop it.  It does seem popular...while I was there I overheard a nurse say they had 3 Avastin's going right now.  The tx itself went without incident.  I got Aloxi 1st with some saline - no other drugs, no benadryl or steriods, etc.  It seemed to make me sleepy and I took a very short cat nap, which I NEVER do.  All total it took about 3 hours...ugg. Right now I just feel sorta "off" - can't really say it's one thing...I feel kinda tired, my arms ache (weird!), and my stomach is a little "off" but no nausea. I will take a Zofran before bed.  I am really wondering what I will feel like tomorrow.  I hope okay because a friend said she had time to go wig shopping with me and I'd like a nice big salad before I have any of the low count worries, but we shall see. Trying to think positively! Thanks soooo much for all your support leading up to this.  I appreciate it more than you know.

Posts.Title: Guess Who Got the Vapors at the Surgeon's Today blainejennifer china

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: So I have been having periodic PET scans for 5+ years now.  The only prep I have EVER had was no eating after midnight and drink lots of water (my scans are always early morning).  I have seen here that others have had a different prep and I have asked various people at the facility repeatedly and still get the same answer.  Now I am scheduled for a PET on March 23rd, and they gave me an entire brochure on how to prep!  The day before I'm supposed to not exercise, no caffeine or alcohol, and strictly limit carbs.  Ok, I can do that but I'm just worried...  Is this irrational thinking?.....I'm worried that with such a different prep that they are going to get a "better" scan.  Now, while that is good - I want them to see everything - I'm just stressing that they are going to see something (for example, maybe a spot on a rib) that has been there all along, but was not picked up before due to the different prep.  What I fear is that my onc is going to see that as progression and jump on the chemo bandwagon again.  I guess I will just have to be strong and hold my ground, so to speak.  I have 24 days (but who's counting, right?) till I get the results of the two scans -- will see the onc on March 25th, and I already have some scanxiety, which is kinda unlike me (at least this far out), and I think it's because of the above worries. I feel pretty darn good right now, so I'm choosing to believe the cancer is still stable.  My life goal has become to sit in that exam room on the 25th and say to the onc "I TOLD YOU SO" -- I told you the hormones would work again!!  I want to sit there looking good and healthy and point my finger at him and say SEEE?!!!  You were WRONG!!!   I'm nuts, aren't I?  ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2012 03:50AM Lynn1 wrote: Wow, thank you all so much for so many replies in such a short time!  I'm so appreciative!! Even though I thought I was being long-winded, it's obvious I have left out some information, so please let me clear up a few things and answer some of the questions raised..... There is absolutely no pressure whatsover.  I can easily say "no" and there will be no guilt-trip, etc.  I have worked for this company for over 22 years.  I have worked with the gentleman who asked me at least 10 years.  I promise there is no "hidden agenda" in their asking me.  As TheDivineMrsM said, this truly is an honor to even be asked.  I have already made it clear that I will have final say-so over what is used - they are very OK with that. They see me as this extremely brave/courageous person.  There is a whole thread dedicated to that so I don't want to go there, but just saying, right or wrong, that is their vision of me, and they are trying to do something nice for me I think.  It is a corporate enviornment, but it's also happens to be a Christian organization so their "motivation" is to motivate people, but not in the traditional sense...more a spiritual sense.  I will be talking also about how God figures into all this.  I know religion/beliefs can be very touchy here, so I don't want to get into that too much.  Just please know that their motivation is positive not negative. They do a video on some topic every year so this is not new.  I also was not as clear as I thought (now that I read my post again) about the "theme" of the video.  It is about people who have had "bad" things happen to them - not of their own doing - and have taken a positive approach to it/seen the silver lining/battled back (whatever you want to call it).  The lady who was homeless was a not a deadbeat who didn't pay her bills...she had some very tragic events happen to her that she had no control over.  The drug abuser obviously made her own choices, but had extenuating circumstances that complicated her recovery from the addiction.  I have never been totally secretive about my MBC, but I don't blurt it out to everyone I meet either.  Sometimes people find out later, and say "why didn't you tell me?", and I tell them it's because I don't want to say "Hi, I'm Lynn...nice to meet you...I have MBC".  ;-)   But if it comes up somehow I have never lied about it.  There are many people in my office who do already know my situation.  Having worked there so long, some are almost like family to me.  They know all about it.  Others know to some degree since they have seen me with no hair, etc. in the past.  Even some of our "big wigs" are aware and are extremely supportive work-wise, which I really appreciate.  I guess I have a new question.....I think you all are correct that people who did not already know will be likely to "see" me differently.  In what ways do you think that will materialize?  Just the questions (how are you?  how do you feel?) or something else?  I guess I'm trying to decide if there is some potential drawback to this that I'm not seeing right now.  Thank you!!!
Posts.Title: Would you do this? Thoughts Please! Lynn1 bhd1

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 12:11AM Lynn1 wrote: Thanks again for your thoughts and opinions! CoolBreeze:  You bring up a good point!!  Given our overall prognosis and my age, I know the odds are against me ever reaching retirement age.  It could happen, I know, but is unlikely.  So I have been looking at it like this is going to be the job I have until I can't work anymore.  I hope it is anyway.  I really like it there and they are kind to me.  I really like your answer (I know it's werid...it's ok).  I think that is an honest and gentle way to handle that.  Thank you! 37Antiques:  That is a great idea!  I could have a sentance or two about how I don't want to be "cancer girl" now.  I just want to be me.  Short and easy to say and very important - at least to me.  I certainly do not want to be doted over now.  LuAnn:  Thank you for your perspective on this.  I see what you are saying.  I'm not sure they have thought about that.  Of course this is going to come up in the interview. It is possible they could change their mind - maybe it's not the happy feel-good story they are going for.  If they do change their mind, I would understand.  In this context though, it is a good time to remind people about dying and their relationship with God.  People like to forget their mortality and think they will do that later. We need to do it now - no one is promised tomorrow...not even healthy people without cancer.  I still very much appreciate your thoughts on this and will give them weight as I make my decision. Scuttlers:  I think you may be misunderstanding the purpose of the video.  It is not meant to be a PSA on MBC.  I am simply sharing my story, including my religious perspective, and was hoping to use a few minutes of that time to also educate folks just a little on what MBC is. That's all. I think what I need to focus on now is the possible negative aspects....that is where my decision will probably lie.   In what way do you think I will be treated differently?  Do you think there will just be more questions, or will I get the "sad face" in the halls?  Those are the negatives,but I also wonder if I might receive more support too?  But is there some "drawback" that I'm not seeing that could come back to bite me?

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I would love to get some advice from those who have been on Abraxane for a long time.  I want to know your experience with hair re-growth DURING treatment. A short history:  I started Abraxane (and Avastin) on July 23rd.  My hair started falling out in clumps about 3 weeks later, so I had it shaved off.  It is almost like it all just released one day, and then started growing back immediately.  I now have about ½" of regrowth.  It is sparse and I'm not sure, even if it were 2 inches long, if it would totally cover but it's still growing!! I can tell it IS getting longer.  The coverage is pretty much the same all over - no bald spots. I'm just looking for stories/experience on this.  Did it fall out again after a few more months?  Does it continue to grow longer and fill in?  Will it fill in enough to go without a wig or some type of wrap eventually? Right now I have a wig I'm somewhat happy with and a few wraps I like, but if this is indeed going to be a long-time thing I need to either get another wig I'm more happy with, or invest in more wraps.  Thanks for sharing your experiences with me. ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Title: Hair -- Abraxane Experience?? Lynn1 jeanne46

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2010 10:31AM - edited Jul 16, 2010 10:32AM by Lynn1 Hi, I took Femara for 5 years - it was a GREAT friend...miss it.  I started it at the same time as I had a hysterectomy, so can't be sure what all was the result of what, but my main complaint was hot flashes - they were intense at times!  Did not have any joint pain or weight gain.  In time, the hot flashes went away for the most part.  I found it a very easy treatment.  I hope you will too!!  Oh, and I took it in the morning -- but if you do find it causes fatigue, take it at night.  My onc told me it really didn't matter what time to him, just as long as I took them regularly.  Hope this helps!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: ......so I guess I was "due" and should not have been surprised, but it came out of nowhere!  First the frustration, then the anger, the screaming and cussing, throwing things, and finally...the tears - great big sobs where you can't catch your breath.  My poor DH just stared at me for most of my meltdown, probably not knowing what to say or do.  In the end, he just held me and hugged me and let me cry big wet spots of tears on his shoulders.  He's so good to me.  This morning, thinking more clearly, I think I know where this truly came from - my decision to cut back on my hours at work.  Today is my first day of that new schedule.  I will be telecommuting every Thursday and Friday.  Part of me is happy about this new arrangement, but -obviously-another part of me is really struggling with this decision.  I know this will be good for me - reduce stress caused by my long commute and the hassles of "office life", but I also feel like somehow this is the first step toward the end....you know, first you telecommute a couple days a week and next thing you know you're dead.  I'm being sarcastic, but that is how my mind sorta jumps ahead.  I feel like I gave in on this decision...like I have given up on a part of this fight.  Maybe it's good I did, I don't know, but right now it doesn't feel good.  I feel like I have failed in some way, but I really can't describe it exactly.  Hopefully someone out there can empathize with me.  I know for so many this decision is very easy and done eagerly, but I'm not feeling that way. I know that in time I will get into a new routine and may even come to really like and accept this decision.  I can see tiny glimpses already - right now, I'm at the computer by a window - the sun is shining and I can see the fall colors on the trees nearby.  My sweet cat is sleeping soundly at my feet.  And yet, I feel the world is going on without me somehow.  Such conflicting feelings today!  Thank you for letting me vent/share.  ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2012 09:17AM Lynn1 wrote: Hi Clarie!  As others have said, even though it sounds scary, it's still just another bone - no different than if they found it in your arm or leg, or hip, etc.  I found this out quite by surprise too and was also freaked out.  I had a regular scan and the onc mentioned that I might have had some very slight progression, but it was so small that we were going to stay the course till the next scan.  I always get a copy of the scan reports so when I get home and am reading it over it says I have something on my skull!  What?!  That was not there before.  So this became a time when I was able to explain to him that I want to know EVERYTHING - even if it doesn't change things overall, I still want to know!  But he did assure me that he didn't mention it just because it didn't change anything - still in just the bone.  Hope this helps your fears some.  HUGS!!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: So today I went for "chemo training".  They did not have this the last time I had chemo, and I have to say it was very helpful.  It was one-on-one with his PA.  She gave me a whole folder full information! This is good for me because I like being "over informed" - always feel the need to do lots of research.  Anyway got all my questions answered - almost.  I asked about the Avastin and she said as of today, they are planning to give it to me, but when I come in on Friday, it's possible that may change. If so, I would get the Abraxane only and no Avastin.  Will just have to wait and see - I hate waiting and I hate not knowing. I get to find out right before. Have I mentioned I hate surprises? *sigh* Now that I have asked the question 100 times in 100 ways, it is finally sinking in and I am so very upset about this situation. I've been holding it together pretty well, but now I'm just a crying mess. This is like a bad dream.  I could possibly be on chemo indefinitely and indefinite chemo means indefinite bald and tired and achey and sick.  This cannot be happening. How come no one around me seems to understand..this is huge! Everyone so nonchalant (sp?) - it will be okay. Yeah, really, you know that?!  This is lifechanging. I'm not ready for this. I'm not.  I don't want to go on Friday even though I know I have to.  How do you all DO this? How do you stay so postive and optomistic? I need to go back to DeNile - so much happier there. I feel like my life is changing...on Friday..day after tomorrow...no going back.  This just sucks. :( ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2012 08:00AM Lynn1 wrote: It seems everyone has very different experiences with this one, so I'll just share my expereience.....When I first started Xeloda both my hands and feet were so sore I could not have much of a mani/pedi, but I went anyway.  I've been going to the same place for years, so they were more than happy to make adjustments for me.  A couple of times I went, it was not much more than a trim and pollish change, but it still made me feel good.  As we adjusted the dose, the side effects lessened and I've been able to add back more and more.  I'm getting regular ones now on my regular schedule.  Just don't be afraid to speak up about what you want done - or not done.  When I was limiting mine so much, they gave me a discount since I didn't get the "full" service. So I think most will be willing to work with you to make you a happy customer.  By the way, the side effects don't show immediately so go get a good one now in case you have to scale back for a few.  Best of luck to you!!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I had my 1st Abraxane 2 weeks ago tomorrow.  I know the general rule of thumb is your hair will begin to fall out 2-4 weeks following your 1st treatment.  This week my scalp/hair has felt "funny", but I dismissed it as me being paranoid - kept thinking/hoping it would be closer to 4 weeks.  I have not seen any hairs on the pillow in the morning and was not noticing much difference at all in the way it looked, etc.  However, this morning I am noticing more and more "stray hairs" -- on the bathroom counter, on my shirt, etc.  It's not a LOT, but I guess it has begun.  My hair was short anyway, but I had it cut to about 2-3" again and I'm not messing with it any more than I have to. Does anyone have any idea how long this "shedding process" will take?  My last chemo was A/C, and once it started to go, it went FAST -- like one day it was starting to come out, and the next day or two it was gone.  Onc said this would be a more "gradual thinning", but it would still come out.  I want to keep it as long as I can and don't want to shave it till it's necessary. Just wondering if anyone has some experience with this and can tell me kinda what to expect....how long will it take to shed enough that I'll need to start wearing a wig/hat/etc? ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 08:19AM Lynn1 wrote: As others have said, sadly there is no quick fix for what we call scanxiety. Everyone deals with it differently too, so you just have to find what works for you.  I try not to dwell on it -- I know, easier said than done.  I wish I could remember who said this to give them proper credit, but I've used this and it works for me sometimes (note: nothing works all the time, unfortunately).  I tell myself that the scans are only telling us what is already going on.  The scan did not change anything and does not change how I feel, etc.  It is what it is and deal with the results when you get them.  Another saying (I'm all about mantras if you can't tell...lol) and again, wish I could remember who has this as their signature, but I love it:  if hope and despair both lead to the same end, which path would you choose?  (I'm paraphrasing so the real author might correct me there, but you get the idea).  Just try and stay as positive as possible, and when that doesn't work, just come here and vent - we get it.  Hugs to you!

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2010 07:57AM Lynn1 wrote: (((Jeanne)))  I also wonder why hair loss has to be one of the se's!  It seems I can deal with most anything else, but the hair, well that's a different story.  I had a similar thing happen with my wig too, but mine was much older (7 years) so not surprised it didn't match now.  Back then I had much longer hair so the wig I got was about shoulder length and was dark brown to match my color back then.  Well, 7 years later, I've still had to keep my hair short (meaning 3" or so) just cause it grew back "different".  I had also started highlighting my hair to cover grays - something I didn't have to do 7 years ago.  So, obviously the old wig looks nothing like my hair now, so I had to go get a totally new one.  I got the synthetic last time and this time, but I have to say that they have come a long way in 7 years - they do look more real.  When I was trying them on, I still felt like they were obvious wigs though - maybe just me being self concious, I don't know - but this lady came in while I had it on and she seemed genuinely shocked that it was not my real hair.  I still think people are going to know (yes, those people you mention that you don't really want to know) because the wig is slightly longer, fuller, and a different shade -- it's subtle in some ways, but I still feel like it's going to be obvious.  I've got some hats/wraps and am toying with the idea of using them, but not sure I'm brave enough. I can sympathize with your fears of being bald from now on.  I know being bald should not matter as long as we are alive and have QOL, but it is the most unfair part to me.  I wish they would figure out a way to treat the cancer and leave our hair alone!!! I hope today finds you up a few rungs on the ladder basking in some sunshine.

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I'm just looking for some thoughts on something I have been asked to participate in.  My company's PR person has approached me about participating in a video project they are doing.  They had asked me about it before, but (long story) it was never done. Now they have approached me again, but this time they want to use it in a different way, and I can't decide if this is a good thing or not.  I think it is, but I'd like to hear your "pros" and "cons" on participating please. This new project will have a video portion that will focus on people who have been put in difficult situations and yet have "stayed the course" so to speak and are doing ok now.  I know they have one person confirmed who became homeless but is now working again,etc, one who fought back from drug addition, and one who is from another country and faced civil unrest.  So it's a very wide variety of "topics" and not sure how many else may join too.  They said they would do a lengthy "interview" with me, but then cut it down to a few scenes for the final version. They assure me I will have total editorial control. I will be able to view their draft and tell them "take that out" or whatever.  The main "pro" that I see is that I can educate some people about MBC - I find that so many have no idea what that really means (no cure, etc.) or what we face every day.  I know having hope will not make my cancer go away, but I know so many just give up immediately - even at lower stages.  If I could help just one person see that having BC, and even MBC, is not always an immediate death sentance, I think that would be valuable to me personally.  The main "con" I see though is that EVERYONE is going to know I have MBC now.  At this moment, it is not obvious.  I have hair and overall I know I look like nothing is wrong to the outside observer.  This video is going to be shared not only with everyone at my office (200+ people), but also made available to over 400 field offices and eventually will be on the Internet.  So what do you think?  Is this good or bad?  Good that I can tell my story to loads of people, or bad because loads of people are now going to know my "secret"?? I have a week to consider this.  They will start filming those who want to participate soon because they are wanting to premiere this in May. I would love to hear your thoughts.  Thank you for your time in reading this....I think I got a little long-winded there. ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2011 10:32PM Lynn1 wrote: Hi Nancy!  As others have already said, not everyone gets it and then some only have very mild cases.  The key (I think) is to let your onc know at the very first signs of any symptoms.  Do not wait thinking it will just go away - it won't.  If you catch it early, it is more easily reversed than if you let it get really bad before doing anything.  The creams and lotions do help (Bag Balm works best for me, but I tried lots before finding one that worked for me).  Reducing your dose is really the only way to reduce symptoms long-term.  We have mine at a level now that is working per my last scans and only results in mild peeling and redness - definitely doable.  As for your trip, just plan ahead, but definitely go!  I am planning to visit Savannah in about a month and it is a "walking town" -- you walk everywhere.  I have found that thicker socks provide more cushion than you'd think and I will wear comfy sneakers, and be diligent with my Bag Balm.  I may have to take some breaks from time to time, but it's not going to stop me from going and enjoying my vacation to the fullest!  Please feel free to PM anytime you have questions or just want to chat/vent.  HUGS!!

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2012 04:54AM - edited Jun 8, 2012 05:31AM by Lynn1 Hi Cat!  So sorry to hear about your prgression.  As with any chemo, we all have such varied responses to it.  I consider myself one of the very lucky ones who does not have the horrible se's on Xeloda.  When I first started taking it, I did have worse se's, but we played with the dose a bit and now it's not bad at all.  I've seen several different people say that they have read where people are being given too high a dose of this, and I think that might be true!  I was very surprised that even a 300mg a day reduction really reduced my se's.  I know it's scary moving to a new chemo and not knowing how you will react to it.  I hope you will be like me and have very few se's on Xeloda.   I LOVE being able to just take some pills and not have to go deal with all IV stuff and sitting around in the cold infusion room.  It's definitely a bonus - at least to me.  You said you've read the threads so you probably already know many of the things you can do to counteract the se's if they do appear.  If there is anything I can do, any questions I can answer, please let me know.  I've been on X for almost a year now (wow, has it been that long?) so maybe I could help in some way.  HUGS!!  PS - edited to add....and you get to keep your hair!  :)

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2012 05:14PM Lynn1 wrote: Bev, I am so sorry!  While I was very fortunate with se's from most of the AI's, I had quite a time with Aromisin.  I took it for a few weeks and cried "uncle" - I was miserable!  My suggestion would be to schedule a time to talk with your onc.  Make sure he knows just how much pain you are in - give him examples of things you can no longer do because of the se's from this AI.  Have you tried a pain patch yet?  I was looking into them recently and they are long-lasting (12-24 hours) and they say they do not cause the nausea as pills do.  Something to ask about anyway. If things are stable, maybe a month off would help?  I'd discuss that option with him too.  I wish I had more advice to offer.  I hope you get some answers soon.  Gentle warm hugs for you!!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: Today is my birthday!!  I was originally dxd 4/03; dxd with mets 11/04 at the age of 35.  Today, I will turn 42....so 6+ years living with mets!  I hope I have at least 6 more yet to come!  I'm going to celebrate a lot this year - I feel I deserve it.  Not doing anything BIG, but something planned today, Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday.  It's like a birthWEEK!  ;-) Tomorrow is also a milestone of sorts.....10 weeks since my last chemo!  I am starting to really feel like myself again.  My hair is back for the most part and I've started going without hats most of the time; you can see my eyebrows without having to be 2" from my face, and my lashes are long enough for mascara!!  The neuropathy in my fingers is improving (boy am I glad that one is getting better!)  I did my first "formal" exercise in many months - walked 2 miles! - I was so proud of myself.  My overall energy is coming back, and I'm starting to do normal things again.  Life is good!!!  I feel so blessed.  I cherish every day now with a sense of appreciation I've never had before.  So I'm celebrating my life, eating desserts, and doing the happy dance. Won't you join me?!  ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Started Afinitor/Femara 10/15/12 Log in to post a reply

I have several hats/caps/wraps/scarves, but my problem is with matching them to my outfit for the day. Some are easy, but sometimes I have nothing that really seems to match and I can't afford to buy one in every color.  What colors are neutral enough to go with many things?  Is a cream/oatmeal color a good one to get or is it too light?  I wear a LOT of blacks and greys, but I've heard from many that black is too "harsh" to wear that close to your face.  I have trouble finding items in grey for some reason.  Also, do I try and match to the top I'm wearing or the bottoms?  I have many clothes that I don't wear anymore because I don't know how to match up my hat!!  Help!! Oh, and as far as coloring goes...I have fair skin, but not overly so (I tan easily in the summer), I have green eyes, and the hair that is coming back in is a medium to light brown.  Thank you! ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 12:01AM Lynn1 wrote: Jeanne - actually they ran it all in "regular time" -- the 1st saline/Aloxi took about 20 minutes, the Avastin was 30, the Abraxane was 30, and then a final saline of another 20 minutes to make sure I got all the Abraxane.  The other time was spent doing blood work, taking BP etc, and seeing the onc.  So the 3 hours was start to finish, not just the IV - sorry that was misleading. Speaking of the drugs, I joked when she said they were going to run the last saline to make sure I got all the Abraxane in the lines, etc.  I said, oh yeah, I paid for that and that's probably $100 there.  She looked at the lines and laughed and said "more than that".  I can only imagine what all this is costing. I am so very grateful for insurance and for having met my out of pocket this year so they are paying 100% right now.  This morning I still feel a bit "off", but not too bad.  A little tired, achey, but still no real nausea.  I took another Zofran this morning just to be safe.  So far, everything still tastes the same, but will keep the tips in mind for when that time comes. Thanks! So far, my only complaint is a bit of constipation.  I'm going to get some Colace today - I remember that working last time.  Anyone have any other remedies? FightnF8 - (very clever screen name btw! love it!) thank you for those tips on staying positive.  I really appreciate it.  I want my "fight" back and I know it will come..I just feel a bit overwhelmed right now, but I hope this will pass soon. I'm still planning on wig shopping today with my friend.  Not a fun chore, but I chose my shopping companion wisely...she will have me laughing in no time.  Hoping my "yucky day" will be tomorrow and I can go to work on Monday. Thanks for all your support!!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: .....those are the words that keep running through my head.  I keep thinking that there has to be some mistake.  I feel like someone has literally pushed me down - like some big bully on the playground.  I really do feel like I'm trying to get back up, brush myself off, and find my way again.  I'm hurt, confused, angry, and sad. How in the world are these mets so out of control when I feel so good?  I guess I always figured that when I had progression/failed a chemo I would have some sort of symptom or at least feel "off", but I feel great! I'm working full-time, exercising 2-3 times a week, traveling, and just doing "normal" stuff.  I look like the picture of health - my color is back, my hair has grown quite a bit, and I finally lost about 10 pounds.  If you did not know, you would never guess I have MBC. So I'm finding it very difficult to wrap my mind around this new news and accept the fact that in a short amount of time all this is going to change.  I know everyone has different reactions to every chemo, but none of them sound very "friendly" to me.  All I can think is I'm going to be tired, sick, and bald from now on.  It's like some sick joke.....yes we want you to voluntarily opt to make yourself miserable.  I know that if I don't do anything, the cancer will take over, but it is incomprehensible to me right now to "do" this to myself.  Does this make any sense?  I guess I'm just rambling here, venting, whatever you want to call it. I don't recognize myself anymore either - I am a "glass half-full" girl - no matter what, I can always see the silver lining, but I just feel despair right now.  I hope that part of me is not gone.  I don't want this stupid cancer to take away the fun in my life...to take away "me".  Usually I'm the one being the cheerleader, and I'm trying to take my own advice, but maybe I just need a push in right direction?  Tell me to shut up and shake it off!  Don't hug me because now they make me cry.  I'm my own worst enemy right now and I don't know how to stop!!  ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2012 10:36AM Lynn1 wrote: UPDATE: I saw my onc today and we have a new plan in place.  I told him how I felt, and at least he acknowledged my feelings - that it is harder to accept this type of news when you feel so good and all.  Still doesn't change anything though!  *sigh* He seemed a tad upset that I had declined the trial, but I would have had to travel a long way in a lot of traffic to participate, and the thought of doing that every week already had me stressed.  I don't need any more stress right now!  So, I have decided on Navelbine.  I will see a surgeon on Tuesday to discuss getting a port, and then we will schedule the first treatment after that.   Most likely it will be on July 13th.  I find that date so ironic.  I started Xeloda on July 12th, so almost one year to the day!!  I'm still in a bit of a funk over all this, but am slowly coming to terms with it all I suppose.  I'm dreading starting this like you can't even imagine, so I'm just going to try and enjoy these next couple of weeks.  I feel like it may the last time I ever feel good again.  I know, that's a defeatist attitude...I'm still working on some areas of acceptance!

Posts.Content: May 11, 2010 10:01AM Lynn1 wrote: Thank you everyone for your replies!!  It is neat to see so many starting about the same time. Not that we want to have this in common, but it does help to not feel so alone.  Yes, I know that fatigue was not listed as a SE....I have decided it falls under "flu like symptoms", but could be wrong.  I have had some minor sore throat pain, but I live in GA and it's polllen season so I just attributed it to that.  ??  To explain my "loading dose".....they are giving me the shot every 2 weeks for 3 times and then I will go on monthly shots.  The 3 so close together are what they are calling the "loading dose".   I've never had much SE (thankfully) from the Zometa.  I little tired, but not bad.  But that is why I was wondering if it was a combinaton of that and the Faslodex at the same time.  I guess I'll just wait and see what the 3rd shot brings.  Renee - so funny you say that about repairing the mets.  That is how I'm looking at it too -- but I picture little pac-men sort of creatures running around my body eating up all the estrogen -- the pain I feel is the cancer starving to death!  Crazy, I know, but it helps!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: .....those are the words that keep running through my head.  I keep thinking that there has to be some mistake.  I feel like someone has literally pushed me down - like some big bully on the playground.  I really do feel like I'm trying to get back up, brush myself off, and find my way again.  I'm hurt, confused, angry, and sad. How in the world are these mets so out of control when I feel so good?  I guess I always figured that when I had progression/failed a chemo I would have some sort of symptom or at least feel "off", but I feel great! I'm working full-time, exercising 2-3 times a week, traveling, and just doing "normal" stuff.  I look like the picture of health - my color is back, my hair has grown quite a bit, and I finally lost about 10 pounds.  If you did not know, you would never guess I have MBC. So I'm finding it very difficult to wrap my mind around this new news and accept the fact that in a short amount of time all this is going to change.  I know everyone has different reactions to every chemo, but none of them sound very "friendly" to me.  All I can think is I'm going to be tired, sick, and bald from now on.  It's like some sick joke.....yes we want you to voluntarily opt to make yourself miserable.  I know that if I don't do anything, the cancer will take over, but it is incomprehensible to me right now to "do" this to myself.  Does this make any sense?  I guess I'm just rambling here, venting, whatever you want to call it. I don't recognize myself anymore either - I am a "glass half-full" girl - no matter what, I can always see the silver lining, but I just feel despair right now.  I hope that part of me is not gone.  I don't want this stupid cancer to take away the fun in my life...to take away "me".  Usually I'm the one being the cheerleader, and I'm trying to take my own advice, but maybe I just need a push in right direction?  Tell me to shut up and shake it off!  Don't hug me because now they make me cry.  I'm my own worst enemy right now and I don't know how to stop!!  ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Title: How is this happening?!?.... Lynn1 cmhartley

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 12:36PM Lynn1 wrote: I know that steroids can cause weight gain, but I've never had that with any of the AI's and I was on all of them.  For me, it really did come down to eating and exercise.  I had very incorrect information about food, but when I joined Weight Watchers and they showed me how things that seem "healthy" are really not and are full of fat and calories, I "saw the light".  It was not easy -- very difficult really because it truly IS a lifestyle change.  You have to make the committment long-term (another thing I was not doing).  In the end, I lost a total of 50 pounds on WW.  I don't go to the meetings anymore, and I don't even follow their new plan, but I remember all they taught me and I do my own "plan" now.  Sparkpeople.com is a great place to log your food intake and exercise.  I have kept the weight off for several years now.  It creeps back up from time to time, and I always look at my diet, and can easily see where I'm "off".  These days, I'm just not hungry much so diet is not the problem as much, but I'm getting all flabby and need to get back to exercising!  It is too easy right now for me to say "later" and then never exericse.   Best of luck to you.  It's hard, but you're worth it!!!
