Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 11:36AM Lynn1 wrote: Another update:  I thoroughly researched the possible bladder condition, and of the many symptoms listed, I only have one (the pelvic pain), so I just really don't think that's it.  And I don't want the other surgery unless it is my only option.  I was looking at my calendar and when all this happened, and the pain started about 1 week after I started the Fareston. So I pulled out the info you get from the pharmacy, and it said to notify your doctor if you had: pain or pressure below your naval, abdominal or stomach pain, or pain or swelling in the groin.  Sounds familar!  So I called the onc's office yet again (they are going to get so sick of hearing from me!).  I am going to stop taking the pill for a week or two and see if the symptoms get any better.  They assured me that a 1 or 2 week break would not put me at any risk cancer-wise.  So, we'll see what happens.  Today is my first day without it, so obviously no change yet. Also, my onc has sorta gotten back in my good graces...he had a nurse call me Monday morning to check on me and see how I was doing.  He has NEVER done that before.  I'm still angry at him -- he's on probation!  LOL!   Seriously though, I now wonder if his message got miscommunicated to me through the nurse that called me back.  ??  I was just super angry when I made the first post.  I don't take it all back, but I guess time is tempering my thoughts now.  I'm not an overly religious person, but I just *feel* that God is telling me not to leave him - at least not right now.  I don't know why, but I know that He has it all planned out, so I will trust my gut for now and see how things go.  Thanks for listening ladies!!!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I had my 1st Abraxane/Avastin 2 weeks ago tomorrow.  I know the general rule of thumb is your hair will begin to fall out 2-4 weeks following your 1st treatment.  This week my scalp/hair has felt "funny", but I dismissed it as me being paranoid - kept thinking/hoping it would be closer to 4 weeks.  I have not seen any hairs on the pillow in the morning and was not noticing much difference in the way it looked, etc.  However, this morning I am noticing more and more "stray hairs" -- on the bathroom counter, on my shirt, etc.  It's not a lot, but I guess it has begun.  My hair was short anyway, but I had it cut to about 2-3" again and I'm not messing with it any more than I have to. Does anyone have any idea how long this "shedding process" will take?  My last chemo was A/C, and once it started to go, it went FAST -- like one day it was starting to come out, and the next day or two it was gone.  Onc said this would be a more "gradual thinning", but it would still come out.  I want to keep it as long as I can and don't want to shave it till it's necessary. Just wondering if anyone has some experience with this and can tell me kinda what to expect....how long will it take to shed enough that I'll need to start wearing a wig/hat/etc? ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. That is why she referred me back to you!  I asked, well now what?  And she did not know so I asked her to talk to him again and see what I should do now.  At almost 5:00 (so now I've been waiting ALL day), she calls back and says, "he said that you just had scans in that area a month ago, and there was nothing wrong so there is nothing to do right now. if it gets worse then call for an office visit".  WTH?!?!?!  Yes, let's just wait and let it get worse before you do anything.  Would it kill you to just order another CT scan or SOMETHING.  DO SOMETHING, ANYTHING.  Argh!  So that was my final straw.  He has done this to me before when I kept telling him my hip hurt and he wouldn't do anything till after I had been to several doctors only to find out in the end it was from mets in my pelvis bone.  So if he does not care about me, then I don't care to see him again.  I've been trying to search for a new one through my insurance website, but I keep getting directed back to him or someone is his group.  I don't know what to do.  I guess there are not a lot of oncs nearby?  I tried once before to go see another doctor in his group and while I was waiting for the other doctor, he saw me and just took over.  I never did get to see the other doctor.  In a way that would be sorta awkward anyway I guess to continue going to the same place but seeing another doctor? And, I don't know what to do about this current situation.  I think I'll call the obgyn on Monday and see if she will either order a scan of some kind or at least refer me to someone.  Right now I have no idea where to go.   Anyway, thanks for letting me vent.  ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I could be the poster child for worrywarts right now.  I have 3-month scans tomorrow morning to see how the Faslodex is working.  I have been dealing with mets for over 5 years and I'm not sure I've ever been this worried, frazzled, and almost bi-polar in my mood swings.  The what-ifs are driving me crazy!  I don't even know how to prepare.  Onc has already said that if there is only slight progression, we could try one more hormonal drug, but otherwise it looks like chemo for me.  I had chemo in 2003 and have been extremely blessed to have been kept stable with only hormones and zometa all this time.  I realize this is not necessarily the norm, and I worry that my streak of good luck has ended.  I am not prepared to enter the chemo realm again.  I know it's my only option, but surely not a good one.  I totally know this is falling on many deaf ears right now of those who have been on chemo for a long time (and I truly admire you like you will never know!), but maybe there is someone out there in a similar situation?  I hope someone can relate.  I'm a mess and the tests aren't even till tomorrow!!  I never get this wound up so early in the process.  I don't get the results till Friday.  And, usually my hubby goes with me to get results, but he's at a new job and with no time off, they are not understanding, and he can't push the issue and lose his job - we need his paycheck!  I am facing the possibility of going alone to this one.  I know I'm a big girl, I should be able to do this, but I'm worried.  I worry, worry, worry all the time.  I want it to stop!  I want to go back to being the positive "glass half full" person I was a few months ago.  Has all that ended now?  I know, no one knows, but this week is almost torture to me, and no one seems to get it - not hubby, friends, or co-workers.  Anyway, as my subject said....this is just ramblings - I can't even seem to think straight lately and I'm at work!!  I have to work all I can because I have so few sick days left.  Of course it's probably better to be here than home alone worrying even more.  Ok, I'll shut up now cause this is really rambling now.  Anyone still reading, thank you so much for just listening!! ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2012 08:50AM - edited Jul 18, 2012 08:51AM by Lynn1 It is not for me, but everyone is different.  With this last progression, the PET said I was fine, the MRI said things were not fine at all.  I would ask for at least a CT scan, if not an MRI.  At least that way you can put your mind at ease and know for sure what is going on.  It could be non-cancer related....arthritis or something like that maybe?  Edited to add:  Bone scans are not reliable for me either - they did not pick up several mets that were seen on the CT scan.
Posts.Title: how is bone mets discovered bhd1 Cynthia1962

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2012 11:08AM Lynn1 wrote: 4myangels:  Here is what I understand -- someone can correct me if I'm wrong..... PET scan looks for metabolic activity -- cancer will be active and will draw the radioactive stuff to those areas where cells are dividing rapidly. Bone scan sees only bones, no other organs, etc.  It also uses some type of radioactive drug to detect these spots. CT scan sees everything -- organs, bones, muscles, etc.  Hope this helps some!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I need to start out by saying that while I like the subdivision we live in, people are not the most friendly.  We have lived there 7 years and hardly know any neighbors.  Everyone keeps to themselves, and that's fine with us too actually. However, in the past few weeks I have noticed a lady out walking.  She is wearing a pink hat (no hair).  I made the assumption that she has breast cancer (from the pink), but I don't know that.  I have ran into her a couple of times when I'm taking the trash out or something like that.  I've always said "hello" or "good morning" and she always replies - seems friendly.  But I keep thinking that I should say more....introduce myself and all, but with all the threads lately about people saying the wrong thing, I'm not sure if that is the best thing to do.  What if she is Stage I and I scare the poo out of her being Stage IV?  What if she just wants to be left alone on her walks and not talk about cancer to anyone?  And then I think, but maybe she is scared and has no one to talk to.  For now, I have hair so it's not obvious that I have cancer and she would have no way of knowing that.  So, if it were you, what would you want me to do?  Leave you alone, or approach you?  If I were to approach, what should I say?!  Hi, I have cancer too.  That just seems sorta awkward.  Maybe there is no good way, maybe I should just leave her alone and mind my own business, but I keep feeling inside like I should say something.  I don't know what is best. Would love your to hear your thoughts on this.  Thanks! ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Started Afinitor/Femara 10/15/12 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: What would you do/say? Lynn1 chele

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2010 01:31PM Lynn1 wrote: I was on Zometa once a month for over 5 years.  I still remember the 1st one...was fine the day of, but the following day I was so achey and tired.  After that, they were no so bad, and near the end of those 5 years, I had so SE's at all.  Some things that helped me were to take 2 Tylenol right before (I'd take mine in the parking lot and then go in for the tx), drink plenty of fluids, and try to stay active -- and by active I don't mean you have to run a marathon, but just don't go home and sit on the couch all night - go for a short walk, clean your house, wash your car, anything but just sit.  Can't guarantee that these will help you, but I hope they will!!  Best of luck to you!!

Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: I have been a "gym rat" for years; going 3-4 times a week at my best.  I lost 50 pounds on Weight Watchers and was working on toning and firming when I found out about the progression in the pelvis.  I looked back at my calendar and the last time I went to the gym was late June! That was right before our trip to MN and I got the news the week after we got back.  I haven't been back to the gym since!!  That's 3 whole months!  My membership fee is pretty low.  I called and I can "freeze" my account for a few months and can still keep my good monthly fee. This may be my best option?  I guess I am reluctant to give up this part of my life, but I don't want to avoid reality. I would love to go back because, as I said, I enjoyed it so much.  But, since starting chemo, I don't have the same energy.  I've read where it's better to be active than sedentery.  I'm not sure if I should push myself into some formal exercise or not.  I've never been good at working out at home - I've had tons of home equipment over the years, and it always ends up collecting dust.  Do I drop the gym and force myself to work out at home, or do I just give up ever exercising again?  I'm just looking for some advice...a reality check...whatever you want to call it.  I know this is trivial in some ways, but welcome your input.  Thank you! ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Lynn1 wrote: So yesterday after I got home from work, we realized we needed a few things from the store.  DH was going to go by himself, but I decided I should get out - I'm becoming such a hermit!  I really didn't want to put my wig back on, so I took a HUGE leap and went with just a cotton wrap thingy on - 1st time ever!  We just went to Wal Mart so I figured I'd be safe there - LOL!  I'm not sure what I expected the "general public" to do, but it went fine...no one pointed or laughed or did any of the crazy things I had imagined. DH asked as we were leaving how I was feeling.  I told him that I felt a bit conspicuous, but no more really than I do in the wig.  I know outwardly there is a big difference, but inside I felt the same - only more comfortable...no itching!  And it was 105 here yesterday so I was cooler too!  I have another friend coming over on Saturday to take a look at this wig and see if she can help me with it.  She has been a stylist for years and years - don't know why I didn't think of her sooner.  Anyway, I'm also thinking about getting another wig too -- take her with me and get some "professional advice" on what to buy.  I'm wondering if a shorter version might be better - this one is short, but not as short as I'm used to so maybe that is what is throwing me off? Anyway, just wanted to share my "brave" story of leaving the house sans wig with those who can really understand.  :) ~Lynn ER+, HER2- Bone mets: sternum, pelvis, spine, ribs....it's everywhere. Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 03:21PM Lynn1 wrote: Well, I just got home from the OBGYN.  She has referred me back to my onc.  CRAP!  Now I'm super worried again.  She did a pelvic exam and hit on one spot there that hurt so bad I almost came off the table.  Obviously, it should not be that tender.  She said there were several things it could be -- scar tissue, the intersistial cystitus someone already mentioned, an internal hernia, or...mets.  Noooo!!  So I came home and called my onc and of course he is not in today, but they promise to call me tomorrow to let me know what he thinks we should do.  ARGH!  WHY?!  Why does this have to happen when things were going so well?  I'm trying not to focus on it being a possible met, but I can't help it.  This is going to seem like a long night waiting to hear from them tomorrow.  Please keep crossing your fingers and toes that it's not mets and can be resolved with some other treatment or something.  I just don't even know what to think right now.  :(

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2010 12:27PM Lynn1 wrote: Thanks everyone!  I knew you'd "get it"!  :) Ginger(Stefanie) - you look beautiful in your profile pix - it's no wonder you got lots of compliments! Jleigh:  awww, I'm so sorry!  I thought you were going to the be one of the ones to keep yours too - you went so long with it still there!  Mine was the same way...ok one day, the next morning I had handfulls of hair in the shower - very distressing!  It does SUCK majorly!!  And I wonder the same thing...will I ever have hair again?!  It's just almost too sad to think about.  I'm gonna stay in DeNile for another few days on that subject for sure. Chainsawz:I guess that is what I thought too - lots of stares.  DH said he was watching others' "reactions" in the store and saw none - yep, none!  Well, he said one lady did look, but then I assume realized the "need" and quickly averted her eyes.  I've been guilty of this myself - you see something that catches your eye so you look and then realize "oh, how rude of me" and look away.  I can accept that kind of thing. njbhwgirl:  I wear a turban to bed too - keeps my head warm at night.  You are right...we are all so different....we have to do what is best for us.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Left Wig at Home! Lynn1 gena
